Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Evaluation of Mantle Xenoliths from the Fosdick Mountains, Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The PI proposes an investigation of mantle xenoliths entrained within a suite of ~1.4 Ma mafic volcanic centers in the Fosdick Mountains, Antarctica. These recently entrained mantle xenoliths offer a unique opportunity to characterize the West Antarctic lithospheric mantle that has been subject to active modification from Cretaceous to Present by plate-boundary processes, such as orthogonal to oblique plate convergence, intracontinental rifting, continental breakup, and Neogene volcanism. These volcanic centers derive from heterogeneous mantle sources and host a compositionally diverse suite of mantle xenoliths that have varied mineral assemblages and microstructures. The proposed research has two complementary goals: to assess structural and compositional heterogeneity within the upper mantle and the variability of intrinsic and extrinsic variables at a variety of lithospheric levels; and to use textural and compositional characterization of the xenolith suite to elucidate possible causes of heterogeneous seismic anisotropy within the Marie Byrd Land mantle lithosphere and inform competing hypotheses explaining the active volcanism, thermal anomaly, and slow seismic velocities beneath West Antarctica. Furthermore, characterization of samples of the mantle beneath West Antarctica provides a type of 'ground truth' in support of contemporary ANET/POLENET seismology research that seeks to determine mantle composition, temperature, and sources of seismic anisotropy.

Broader impacts:
The PI is in his first-year as a tenure track faculty member at Boston College. A postdoctoral researcher will be trained in EBSD techniques, interdisciplinary polar research, and the mentoring of undergraduate investigators. Two Boston College undergraduates will participate in the research and a priority will be placed on selecting underrepresented minorities and first-generation college students. An existing sample suite assembled over more than 20 years of NSF sponsored field work, will be used. The PI will create a digital database for microstructural, textural, and xenolith data for rapid dissemination to the international Antarctic community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth’s tectonic plates are composed of rocks belonging to the crust (the thin, compositionally heterogeneous outer layer of the Earth), and to a portion of the uppermost mantle – the mantle lithosphere. Composed primarily of the minerals olivine and pyroxene, the chemical and mechanical properties of upper mantle rocks (i.e. peridotites) exert a fundamental control on the strength and deformational behavior of the tectonic plates. Our understanding of upper mantle processes has largely been quantified through experimental rock deformation and geophysical studies, and through investigations of naturally deformed mantle rocks brought to the surface through tectonic processes associated with mountain building events, or as peridotite xenoliths, i.e. inclusions of mantle rocks in deep-sourced volcanic lavas.

This study examines a suite of peridotite xenoliths entrained within lavas sourced from several volcanic centers in Marie Byrd Land, West Antarctica (Fosdick Mountains, Usas Escarpment, and Executive Committee Range). Our study integrates a variety of analytical methods that allow for the characterization of rock microstructure (fabric), crystal 3D shape and preferred orientation, and rock composition (major element chemistry, volatile / water content) in order to quantify the physical and chemical properties of mantle lithosphere that give rise to variations in the strength and deformational behavior of tectonic plates. Current knowledge on mantle deformation processes is rooted, in part, in elucidating the variables (e.g., water content, stress and temperature) that control the development of olivine and pyroxene crystal preferred orientations, which largely describe the orientation of mantle flow and tectonic plate movement inferred from geophysical and geodetic studies.

Our new data from the Marie Byrd Land xenoliths suggest that the deformation to which mantle rocks were exposed also exerts a significant control on the development of crystal preferred orientations. We demonstrate that olivine crystal preferred orientations may develop as a result of the three-dimensional geometry of the deformation, rather than reflect the deformation conditions experienced in the upper mantle (which is the common assumption in mantle fabric studies). To arrive at this conclusion, we used X-ray computed tomography (XRCT; essentially a CATscan applied to a rock) in conjunction with electron microscopy techniques as a solution to the problem of determination of grain shape fabric in xenolith studies. By their nature, xenoliths are removed from their structural context in the upper mantle. XRCT allows for characterization of 3D grain shape fabrics in mantle materials, thereby providing a critical reference framework for the unbiased interpretation of olivine crystal orientation data and identification of intra-crystalline mechanisms that facilitate deformation. The intra-crystalline deformation mechanisms are of particular importance for studies of the lithospheric mantle beneath continental crust where xenoliths comprise the main source of direct information. To our knowledge, this is the first known application of combined quantitative XRCT and electron microscopy in mantle fabric studies.

Further, we characterize the chemical compositions of the Marie Byrd Land xenoliths to show the lithospheric mantle beneath West Antarctica exhibits significant lateral and vertical heterogeneity on scales that are smaller than the resolutions attainable using contemporary geophysical methods. Calculated equilibration temperatures for coexisting minerals in the xenolith suite indicate that they were sourced from depths ranging from 39-72 km, and temperatures corresponding to 780-1200ºC. These observations suggest that the Marie Byrd Land xenoliths record compositional and structural heterogeneities resulting from mantle flow and deformation that are more complex than previously documented, particularly in naturally deformed mantle materials.

This award supported one post-doctoral researcher, a Masters degree student, and undergraduate research projects at Boston College. The activities associated with this award also formed the core research efforts of Seth C. Kruckenberg, an early career faculty member, during the development of his new research program an analytical facility at Boston College. Significant results from this research are the subject of numerous conference presentations, a Masters thesis at Boston College, and a number of peer-reviewed manuscripts either published (e.g., Chatzaras et al., 2016, Journal of Geophysical Research) or nearing completion.
